meta.name: description
meta.content: Normally, at this time of year the halls of D.C. Everest Senior High would be teeming with high school students, instructors and staff members working toward the close of the academic year.

Normally, at this time of year the halls of D.C. Everest Senior High would be teeming with high school students, instructors and staff members working toward the close of the academic year.

h1.span: D.C. Everest Hydroponic Farm Provides Fresh Leafy Greens for Families Impacted by Coronavirus

div.p: Normally, at this time of year the halls of D.C. Everest Senior High would be teeming with high school students, instructors and staff members working toward the close of the academic year. Today, as the COVID-19 pandemic continues, the building houses construction crews working on the final stages of the districts #FutureReady updates and a small crew led by AgriScience, Technology and Engineering Teacher John Glynn overseeing Evergreen Farms, a vertical hydroponic growing system in the schools newly-opened Tech Ed center. When the school closed on March 16, Mr. Glynn and Mike Raether, D.C. Everest Senior High Principal, constructed a plan to utilize the hydroponic farm to support the community by providing fresh produce to families in need.

Since then, Glynn has worked with small teams of staff volunteers to grow butterhead lettuce seedlings, transplant them into the vertical hydroponic towers and harvest them three weeks later. The crew transplants 800 two-week-old seedlings at a time on a bi-weekly basis to ensure a fresh crop of lettuce is available each week. The lettuce is then harvested, cleaned and bagged for distribution via the districts Grab-and-Go meal program, which provides meals for community members in need. The meals are distributed Monday Friday in the parking lots of various DCE schools.

Originally, Glynn and his students planned to grow a variety of herbs and vegetables this spring via Evergreen Farms, but for now Glynn is focused on growing lettuce because it is a crop he can reliably grow while meeting the needs of the community. Hes sharing his experiences and lessons learned with students on the D.C. Everest Agriscience Facebook page. My biggest lesson has been to use water that is filtered from the tap. Keeping the air temperature has been a challenge, but I do feel like I finally have the nutrients where they need to be, he notes. Im learning something new every week.

Those lessons are paying off. Not only can DCE and FFA students follow him on social media, members of the community have shared their thanks for the fresh lettuce he works so hard to grow. As one community member noted, We received a head of the lettuce yesterday and had it in a salad for dinner. It is the best homegrown lettuce Ive ever had! Others on social media have asked if the lettuce could be made available at local farmers markets. Thats certainly a possibility for the future, but for now Mr. Glynn and his team will continue to produce the fresh leafy greens for families impacted by COVID-19. The week of March 30 April 3, 5,862 childrens meals, 1,802 adult meals and 200 family weekend meal bags were distributed through the Grab-and-Go meal program.
Karen Wegge, John Glynn and Aaron Hoffman are ready to plant 800 lettuce seedlings.
All Content 2018 D.C. Everest Area School District
